items.synopsis: The caucus of official advocates says a national First Nations children's commissioner is needed to address "critically high" levels of disadvantage.

title.children: Advocates launch 'urgent' call for national commissioner for Indigenous children

image.altText: A mother and father holding their young daughter between them, smiling. They are standing on an apartment balcony.

items.synopsis: Medium- and high-density development in established suburbs is being spruiked as the solution to Australia's housing crisis. But there are still some risks.

title.children: Sean and Jane paid $720,000 for an apartment with no car parks and shared laundry. It was their path out of renting

image.altText: Promo image of a line chart showing housing costs broken down by income.

items.synopsis: Housing costs are at record highs, and we can show you who is bearing the brunt of the crisis.

title.children: Where you sit on this chart determines your level of housing stress

image.altText: A young man wearing a black jumper smiles at the camera in front of a green foliage background.

items.synopsis: On a basketball court in a remote town, conversations about sport and feelings are helping open the doors to employment opportunities.

title.children: How an outback pilot program is using sport to provide pathways to employment

image.altText: Vanessa Hudson, the incoming Qantas CEO, with model plane in foreground showing Flying Kangaroo

items.synopsis: With Alan Joyce announcing his abrupt departure from Qantas two months ahead of schedule, Vanessa Hudson is now in control of an airline with a reputation problem — and disgruntled customers say it will be tough to win them back.

title.children: New Qantas CEO Vanessa Hudson faces an uphill battle to restore the public's faith as Alan Joyce departs

image.altText: A man in a dark suit walks down a corridor holding a coffee cup with another man beside him.

items.synopsis: Treasurer Jim Chalmers says there is no need to review the rejection of Qatar's application for more flights to major Australian airports, despite a forthcoming Senate inquiry.

title.children: 'No intention' to review Qatar Airways decision despite Senate inquiry

image.altText: Albanese stands speaking to media from a courtyard.

items.synopsis: The PM will use a speech to the ASEAN summit on Wednesday to release the government's South-East Asian Economic Strategy, a blueprint aimed at driving trade and investment north into the region.

title.children: Anthony Albanese starts summit season talking trade ties and regional security, with China in mind

image.altText: Fighters of Wagner private mercenary group pose for a picture.

items.synopsis: This morning's news, as it happened.

title.children: UK to declare Russia's Wagner Group a terrorist organisation. The latest news with The Loop

image.altText: A man looks on, waving his arms

items.synopsis: Spain's beleaguered football federation sacks the coach of its national women's team, Jorge Vilda, less than three weeks after he oversaw its World Cup triumph in Australia.

title.children: Spain sacks World Cup-winning women's coach as post-tournament chaos continues

image.altText: young girl on bus.

items.synopsis: From war-torn hills and valleys, to the sheep and wheat paddocks of remote Australia, the Karen people are determined to pass down their language and traditions to the next generation.

title.children: Why Karen refugees living in remote Australia finally feel hopeful for the future

image.altText: Man in blue suit stands in front of Israeli flag

items.synopsis: Israel will pay for Papua New Guinea to operate the embassy it opened in the contested city of Jerusalem, according to PNG's Prime Minister.

title.children: Israel to bankroll PNG embassy in the contested city of Jerusalem, PM says

image.altText: An image of a small carpark next to a Middle Arm boat ramp.

items.synopsis: The federal Senate votes to establish an inquiry into the NT government's controversial planned industrial precinct on Darwin Harbour.

title.children: Senate inquiry to scrutinise planned $1.5bn Middle Arm industrial hub near Darwin

image.altText: Two people wearing colourful festival clothes walk through mud with their backs to the camera.

items.synopsis: Burning Man turned to mud. Korea's Scout Jamboree ended in heat, a typhoon, evacuations and recriminations. Extreme weather threatens your favourite festival, writes Andrew King.

title.children: The chaos at Burning Man is a sign of what's to come for summer outdoor festivals

image.altText: Green banana bunches hang upside down in a shed as a man wearing a bright orange cap tends to a bunch.

items.synopsis: Ecuador is wedged between the world's largest cocaine producers, Peru and Colombia, with drug traffickers finding containers filled with bananas to be the perfect vehicle to smuggle their product.

title.children: Security in Ecuador comes undone as drug cartels exploit banana industry to ship cocaine

image.altText: A small chimpanzee on a rope

items.synopsis: The three-year-old chimpanzee — whose surrogate mother rushed to his aid and refused to let go — is recovering after being bitten by the deadly snake in his enclosure at Rockhampton Zoo.

title.children: Gandali the chimp survives snakebite at Queensland zoo after mistaking eastern brown for toy

image.altText: A woman in a grocery isle of fruit and vegetables

items.synopsis: The latest GDP data shows an annual slowdown in the Australian economy because of interest rate hikes.  Follow the day's events and insights from our business reporters on the ABC News live markets blog.

title.children: Economy grows by 2.1 per cent in 12 months, Wall Street falls, Australian dollar tumbles

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: It's a great question — and you might be seeing this phrase around the place today, but it's not something we are going to be widely using here. That's because while people generally have a pretty good understanding of what a recession is, throwing "per capita" in front of it makes it a bit harder to digest. I'll break it down for you though. A recession is generally defined by economists as there being two successive negative quarters of economic growth (or GDP being a negative percentage). But a per capita recession adds the caveat that the country experiences two successive negative quarters of economic growth *per person*. Looking at the GDP per capita in today's figures, we are we can see that it fell by 0.3% in the March quarter, and by 0.3% again in the June quarter — meeting that technical definition for a per capita recession. So what does that actually mean? Basically, it might not *look* like the country is in recession, but it *feels* like one. As for why we're experiencing this decline in GDP per person — it all comes back to the fact population growth is outpacing economic growth when (we ignore immigration). In fact, the RBA forecasted a per capita recession all the way back in May — you can watch Alan Kohler's finance report from May 5 below to hear their reasoning:
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: What's this about a 'per capita recession' and is Australia experiencing one?

children.content: It's a great question — and you might be seeing this phrase around the place today, but it's not something we are going to be widely using here.
That's because while people generally have a pretty good understanding of what a recession is, throwing "per capita" in front of it makes it a bit harder to digest.
I'll break it down for you though.
A recession is generally defined by economists as there being two successive negative quarters of economic growth (or GDP being a negative percentage).
But a
per capita recession
adds the caveat that the country experiences two successive negative quarters of economic growth *per person*.
Looking at the GDP per capita in today's figures, we are we can see that it
fell by 0.3% in the March quarter
, and by
0.3% again in the June quarter
— meeting that technical definition for a per capita recession.
So what does that actually mean? Basically,
it might not *look* like the country is in recession, but it *feels* like one
As for why we're experiencing this decline in GDP per person — it all comes back to the fact
population growth is outpacing economic growth
when (we ignore immigration).
In fact, the
RBA forecasted a per capita recession all the way back in May
— you can watch
Alan Kohler's finance report
from May 5 below to hear their reasoning:

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Consumers are pulling back on spending as higher interest rates and inflation bite, although the latest economic growth figures show a rise in government and business investment. The economy expanded by 0.4 per cent over the June quarter and by 2.1 per cent over the year to June according to the Bureau of Statistics. Services exports rose 12.1 percent driven by travel services as the number of international students and tourists returned as Australia continued to recover from the COVID-19 pandemic. Higher population growth is expanding the economy, but income per person has fallen for the second quarter in a row, essentially a per capita recession. The ABS says that population growth due to post-pandemic migration saw GDP per capital fall 0.3 per cent, following a similar fall of 0.3 per cent in March. ABS head of national accounts Katherine Keenan says the household saving to income ratio fell for the seventh consecutive quarter to 3.2 per cent, its lowest level since June quarter 2008. “The fall in the household saving ratio was driven by higher interest payable on dwellings, income tax payable and increased spending by households due to the rising cost of living pressures," she said. Total income received by households rose 1.8 per cent, driven by interest received and compensation of employees. Sean Langcake from BIS Oxford Economics says net exports bounced back over the June quarter with good weather seeing an increase in mining shipments. But household spending is weak. "Household consumption growth is in the doldrums,      increasing by just 0.1 per cent quarter on quarter." "Spending on discretionary items continues to      fall, with vehicle purchases a lone bright spot. " "Spending on essentials remains      steady, buoyed by the relatively strong pace of population growth."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Consumers pull back but businesses keep spending

children.content: Consumers are pulling back on spending as higher interest rates and inflation bite, although the latest economic growth figures show a rise in government and business investment.
The economy expanded by 0.4 per cent over the June quarter and by 2.1 per cent over the year to June according to the Bureau of Statistics.
Services exports rose 12.1 percent driven by travel services as the number of international students and tourists returned as Australia continued to recover from the COVID-19 pandemic.
Higher population growth is expanding the economy, but income per person has fallen for the second quarter in a row, essentially a
per capita recession
The ABS says that population growth due to post-pandemic migration saw GDP per capital fall 0.3 per cent, following a similar fall of 0.3 per cent in March.
ABS head of national accounts Katherine Keenan
says the household saving to income ratio fell for the seventh consecutive quarter to 3.2 per cent, its lowest level since June quarter 2008.

“The fall in the household saving ratio was driven by higher interest payable on dwellings, income tax payable and increased spending by households due to the rising cost of living pressures," she said.
Total income received by households rose 1.8 per cent, driven by interest received and compensation of employees.
Sean Langcake from BIS Oxford Economics says net exports bounced back over the June quarter with good weather seeing an increase in mining shipments.
But household spending is weak.
"Household consumption growth is in the doldrums,      increasing by just 0.1 per cent quarter on quarter."
"Spending on discretionary items continues to      fall, with vehicle purchases a lone bright spot. "
"Spending on essentials remains      steady, buoyed by the relatively strong pace of population growth."

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: I'm so glad you asked, because the ABS has helpfully distilled it into 11 key takeaways. I won't hit you with them all at once, but here's the first few that mention some terms you'll be familiar with: Inflation continued to moderate. The consumer price index rose 0.8 per cent in the June quarter and was up 6.0 per cent in the past 12 months. This marked the second consecutive quarter of lower annual inflation, down from the peak of 7.8 per cent in the December 2022 quarter. Food prices increased 1.6 per cent during the quarter, and housing costs as measured in the CPI rose 0.8 per cent. Higher interest rates squeezed consumption. Households shelled out $82.8 billion in mortgage interest payable during the year. This was almost double last year’s interest bill. Discretionary household spending fell 0.5 per cent in the June quarter, which was the third quarterly fall in a row. Spending on furnishings and household equipment fell for the fifth quarter in succession, down 3.4 per cent in annual terms. Retail sales fell 0.5 per cent during the quarter, and retail inventories fell sharply. We worked more hours. We spent 2.4 per cent more time at work than we did last quarter, which, excluding the COVID-19 pandemic, was the fastest quarterly increase in hours worked on record. We worked 6.8 per cent more hours this year than last year, and with GDP rising by a smaller amount, labour productivity fell 3.2 per cent in annual terms.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: What happened in the Australian economy in the three months to June?

children.content: I'm so glad you asked, because the ABS has helpfully distilled it into 11 key takeaways.
I won't hit you with them all at once, but here's the first few that mention some terms you'll be familiar with:
Inflation continued to moderate
. The consumer price index rose 0.8 per cent

in the June quarter and was up 6.0 per cent in the past 12 months. This marked the second consecutive quarter of lower annual inflation, down from the peak of 7.8 per cent in the December 2022 quarter. Food prices increased 1.6 per cent during the quarter, and housing costs as measured in the CPI rose 0.8 per cent.
Higher interest rates squeezed consumption

. Households shelled out $82.8 billion in mortgage interest payable during the year. This was almost double last year’s interest bill. Discretionary household spending fell 0.5 per cent in the June quarter, which was the third quarterly fall in a row. Spending on furnishings and household equipment fell for the fifth quarter in succession, down 3.4 per cent in annual terms. Retail sales fell 0.5 per cent during the quarter, and retail inventories fell sharply.
We worked more hours

. We spent 2.4 per cent more time at work than we did last quarter, which, excluding the COVID-19 pandemic, was the fastest quarterly increase in hours worked on record. We worked 6.8 per cent more hours this year than last year, and with GDP rising by a smaller amount, labour productivity fell 3.2 per cent in annual terms.

image.altText: RBA governor Philip Lowe speaks at the Morgan Stanley Australia summit in Sydney

items.synopsis: The public service code of conduct sets out reasons why a Reserve Bank governor should not move to a private bank at the end of the term. But there is nothing to stop Philip Lowe doing so and — as shabby as it seems — he wouldn't be the first, writes Peter Martin.

title.children: With his last interest rates decision made, will Philip Lowe move to a private bank?

image.altText: A woman with a tan jumper and long brown hair leans on a wooden pole on her front porch, looking out to the distance.

title.children: Hannah is one of thousands of home owners seeing the light as RBA leaves rates on hold again

image.altText: A middle-aged man holds a long stick up in a prayer position in front of his face

items.synopsis: Taiwan's iPhone billionaire is running for president with a lofty election promise to broker peace between Taiwan and China. But observers believe his election bid may result in a less China-friendly candidate securing the presidency.

title.children: Taiwan's iPhone billionaire is shaking up the island’s presidential election in his bid to fulfil the wishes of a sea goddess

image.altText: A middle-aged white man in a suit with a yellow tie and glasses yells and points while speaking in parliament.

image.altText: Coco Gauff clenches her fist

title.children: Coco Gauff emulates Serena Williams with straight-sets win, Novak Djokovic cruises through
